chapter.htmlHeader: What are the complications?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
The skin is a barrier to bacteria and moisture loss. When this is breached, potential complications from burns may present soon after injury, or later during the healing process.

Early complications

  • Respiratory distress from smoke inhalation or a circumferential chest burn — smoke inhalation may cause bronchospasm, pulmonary and laryngeal oedema.
  • Poisoning from inhalation of noxious gases released by burning (for example, cyanide poisoning due to smouldering plastics).
  • Fluid loss, hypotension, and hypovolaemic shock (severe burns).
  • Hypothermia — epidermal damage may lead to problems with thermoregulation.
  • Wound infection and sepsis. See the CKS topic on Cellulitis - acute for more information.
  • Toxic shock syndrome — a rare, potentially life-threatening complication of small burns in children caused by strains of Staphylococcus aureus. Typically presents with fever, rash, diarrhoea, irritability, poor feeding, tachycardia, and tachypnoea, and may present 2–4 days post-injury.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias — electrical burns may cause ventricular fibrillation; chemical burns may cause electrolyte disturbances which may precipitate arrhythmias.
  • Vascular insufficiency, distal ischaemia, or compartment syndrome from a circumferential burn of limb or digit.
  • Acute kidney injury — electrical burns may cause widespread muscle damage which generates myoglobin, and damaged red blood cells release haemoglobin, which may present with haematuria. See the CKS topic on Acute kidney injury for more information.
  • Limb loss — high-voltage burns (more than 1000 volts) may cause extensive, deep tissue damage and limb loss.
  • Death — may result from severe, extensive burns or electric shock (currents of more than 70,000 volts may cause cardiac arrhythmias, paralysis of respiratory muscles, and are usually fatal).

Later complications

  • Wound infection. See the CKS topic on Cellulitis - acute for more information.
  • Chronic neuropathic pain and itch.
  • Scarring — burns that take more than 2–3 weeks to heal are more likely to result in hypertrophic scarring (raised, rigid, red scarring which may have altered sensation and pigmentation).
  • Contractures — shortening of the scar and underlying tissues after the wound has closed.
  • Psychosocial impact — such as depression, anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder; changes in body image, stigma, and social isolation following scarring. See the CKS topics on Depression, Depression in children,  Generalized anxiety disorder, and Post-traumatic stress disorder for more information.
  • Sleep disorders such as insomnia, hypersomnia, and nightmares. See the CKS topic on Insomnia for more information.

[Lloyd, 2012; Culleiton, 2013; Wounds International, 2014; Gnaneswaran, 2015]
